comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Ah, the most frequently repeated misquotation in cinema history [it's actually just "Play it, Sam"], but very apt for a Sam Hood photo! :) Judging by the objects on display, this photo was taken at the same time - emuseum.anmm.gov.au/code/emuseum.asp?id=25694

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] A fabulous piano. There's an interesting article on the saloon and interior of the vessel. This photograph was most certainly taken at the same time as the one of Ray Sterling. Judging by how young Ray Sterling looks in the other photograph, this photograph was probably taken between 1912 and 1916.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: OMG! It is a "player piano" according to that newspaper article - that's cheating, Sam! And evidently the dining table turned into a gramophone which played . Caruso singing La bohème.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] It is cheating indeed! And he is sitting there making out like he can play piano ;) We think this photograph depicts the gramophone in the background, what do you think? Although, we're not quite sure how it was part of the centre table...
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] I think the Sterlings collected musical gadgets!  That's got to be a gramophone horn in the background.  The table looks a bit like a coffin!

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/7793039870/in/set-72157630948463146/]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] There's more than just the gramophone in the background. Check out the spooky reflection of the photographer!

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] We think so too, it must be it. I suspect the reflection may be that of Ray Sterling.
The gramophone was supposed to be put into the centre table, though this looks like an earlier photograph than the newspaper article which was dated 1922, so it is quite possibly that E R Sterling had it built in later.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
